messages.text: I don't know about your strategy of building up a blockchain by accrual.  Starting small is fine, still -- you should have a sense of where you are going before you begin.  Perhaps you do.

messages.text: <@UR9TWADMF> I'm as big a diehard fan of Julia, but I would emphatically recommend you check out using other languages for the implementation. Probably Rust.

messages.text: Julia is great - but the cryptography and safety critical ecosystem in Julia is not anywhere near as mature as you would need if you were to earnestly going to start developing blockchains in Julia and putting in millions of other people's money on it.

elements.text: Julia is great - but the cryptography and safety critical ecosystem in Julia is not anywhere near as mature as you would need if you were to earnestly going to start developing blockchains in Julia and putting in millions of other people's money on it.

attachments.title: Blockchain
attachments.text: Where i see Julia adding immediate value is as a higher level language used to generate the evm, michelson and all the other craziness that’s out there. Similar to the idea of emitting web assembly. No need to re-invent the wheel in terms of new cryptographic packages. All that’s needed is a way to write smart contracts in Julia and have the deployment and compilation handled by the native tech. In terms of other relevant cryptos that will likely succeed. EOS (which promises the moon) seems li...

messages.text:
<@U6QGE7S86> Why are there so many proponents for Julia blockchain development?  Even some people who have begun development using Julia.  You're also in that discussion talking about Nettle.jl

Furthermore, why is there a <#CB9TNT6J2|blockchain> channel for Julia if it's not ideal?

elements.text:
Why are there so many proponents for Julia blockchain development?  Even some people who have begun development using Julia.  You're also in that discussion talking about Nettle.jl

Furthermore, why is there a
channel for Julia if it's not ideal?

messages.text:
1. People take on hobby projects in their spare time. We are an OSS community after all.
2. Someone after that discourse post started this channel. No one forces people to work on this, and people come and go as they please.
3. Just because it's not ideal doesn't mean that people won't take on side projects in it.

elements.text: People take on hobby projects in their spare time. We are an OSS community after all.
Someone after that discourse post started this channel. No one forces people to work on this, and people come and go as they please.
Just because it's not ideal doesn't mean that people won't take on side projects in it.

messages.text: In particular, IIUC from that discussion, Julia uses BigInts for some cryptographic primitives which are subject to side channel timing attacks. Those libraries are highly non-trivial to reimplement, and almost surely require some sort of formal auditing process by trained cryptography engineers or such to make sure the bedrock for that sort of ecosystem is legit.

elements.text: In particular, IIUC from that discussion, Julia uses BigInts for some cryptographic primitives which are subject to side channel timing attacks. Those libraries are highly non-trivial to reimplement, and almost surely require some sort of formal auditing process by trained cryptography engineers or such to make sure the bedrock for that sort of ecosystem is legit.

messages.text: Many of those people are in C/C++, Coq, or Rust communities and have built their ecosystems there - it hasn't happened in Julia yet.

elements.text: Many of those people are in C/C++, Coq, or Rust communities and have built their ecosystems there - it hasn't happened in Julia yet.

messages.text: I'm not qualified to give more than a passing summary of perhaps why that is the case.

messages.text: Thank you for taking the time for the extensive input.  Maybe Solidity is also a good route.

elements.text: Thank you for taking the time for the extensive input.  Maybe Solidity is also a good route.

messages.text: There are wrappers available AMCL for assymeyric cryptography. Also I wouldn't buy into a threat model by a side channel attack as an obstacle for developing a secure software. Being aware of it one just can implement a constant pause preventing a remote adversary to act on it. Whereas if adversary can control the system you probably have a bigger problem.

elements.text: There are wrappers available AMCL for assymeyric cryptography. Also I wouldn't buy into a threat model by a side channel attack as an obstacle for developing a secure software. Being aware of it one just can implement a constant pause preventing a remote adversary to act on it. Whereas if adversary can control the system you probably have a bigger problem.

messages.text: I find Julia to be well suited in developing a state machines when the transactions does have a different actions. For instance A manager may make a transaction of adding a member which updates the state in fir the set of members. Whereas member may make a transaction of a coin to another member. Both of these actions check and update the state in a different ways. I find multiple dispatch and Julia type system good to represent such problems.

elements.text: I find Julia to be well suited in developing a state machines when the transactions does have a different actions. Both of these actions check and update the state in a different ways. I find multiple dispatch and Julia type system good to represent such problems.
